properties.areaDesc: Sacramento Mountains Above 7500 Feet; East Slopes Sacramento Mountains Below 7500 Feet; West Slopes Sacramento Mountains Below 7500 Feet
properties.senderName: NWS El Paso TX/Santa Teresa NM
properties.headline: Winter Weather Advisory issued February 4 at 3:13AM MST until February 5 at 5:00AM MST by NWS El Paso TX/Santa Teresa NM
properties.description:
...WINTER STORM TO IMPACT THE SACRAMENTO MOUNTAINS, THE EASTERN
LOWLANDS OF OTERO COUNTY, AND HUDSPETH COUNTY...

.Two rounds of snow will affect the area. The first round is
beginning across the Sacramento Mountains. Snow levels will start
off above 7000 feet by sunrise but drop throughout the day
reaching 6000 feet by evening. Snow may taper off in the afternoon for
a few hours. A strong cold front will begin to move across the
area early Wednesday morning and is expected to bring an increase
in snowfall to the southern portions of the Sacramento Mountains
and lowlands east of the Rio Grande. The heaviest snowfall with
this second round of snow looks to occur across Hudspeth county
and eastern portions of the Otero lowlands. Snow should begin to
exit the area by mid-day Wednesday.

* SNOW AMOUNTS...Total snow accumulations of 2 to 4 inches with
up to 6 inches possible above 8000 feet.

* WHERE...Sacramento Mountains, especially along ridgelines and
east slopes.

* TIMING...Snow is expected this morning through this afternoon,
initially above 7000 feet before gradually lowering to around
6000 feet. Snow may taper off later this afternoon before a
second round of snow begins this evening.

* IMPACTS...Snowfall will create slick roads and reduce
visibility making for hazardous travel conditions. Road closures
will be possible along US 82.
properties.instruction:
Slow down and use caution while traveling.

The latest road conditions for the state you are calling from can
be obtained by calling 5 1 1.

NWSheadline: WINTER WEATHER ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 5 AM MST WEDNESDAY
